Stoeckle History
Overview

how-to-contribute.title: How to Contribute
how-to-contribute.content:
How to Contribute
Send stories, photos, or documents

Email or share a folder with scanned documents, photos, letters, or stories.
Include any known dates, names, and places in a short note.

File naming convention
Use clear, consistent names so files are easy to find:

lastname-firstname-documenttype-year.ext
Example: seehafer-ida-death-cert-1948.jpg

Add a new person/place/source page

Copy the relevant template from content/people/_template.md, content/places/_template.md, or content/sources/_template.md.
Fill in only what you can confirm from sources.
Add TODOs for missing information.

Documents that help most

Death certificates
Obituaries
Probate files
Census records
Church registers

If you are unsure, send the document anyway. We can sort and cite it later.

people/seehafer-clara-f.title: seehafer-clara-f
people/seehafer-clara-f.content:
Clara F. Seehafer
Facts

Died in 1916 at Pontiac State Hospital; cause listed as lobar pneumonia.
Death certificate notes an insanity duration and that the physician attended since 1909-06-24.
Listed in the Ann Arbor City Directory as boarding at 1134 Main N. (1904-1905) and 509 Cedar (1908).
TODO: Confirm burial details beyond the certificate entry.

Death

Date of death: 1916-11-16 at Pontiac State Hospital, Pontiac (Oakland County), Michigan.
Cause of death: Lobar pneumonia; contributory condition listed as insanity.
Birth date listed as 1886-09-23 in Germany.
Parents listed as William Seehafer and Wilhelmina Boelter.
Burial listed at Oak Hill Cemetery.
Source: Michigan Death Certificate: Clara F. Seehafer (1916)

Sources

Michigan Death Certificate: Clara F. Seehafer (1916)

people/seehafer-ida-m.title: seehafer-ida-m
people/seehafer-ida-m.content:
Ida M. Seehafer
Facts

Died in 1948 at Ypsilanti State Hospital.
Cause of death listed as meningioma with cerebral edema; contributory bronchopneumonia.
Usual residence listed as 509 Long Shore Dr.
Listed in the Ann Arbor City Directory as boarding at 509 Cedar (1908-1915) and as a maid at 630 Oxford rd (1916-1918).
Unconfirmed: Family reminiscence notes Ida died in 1948.
TODO: Confirm burial details beyond the certificate entry.

Death

Date of death: 1948-12-08 at Ypsilanti State Hospital, Ypsilanti (Washtenaw County), Michigan.
Cause of death: Meningioma of left parietal hemisphere with cerebral edema; contributory bronchopneumonia and malnutrition.
Birth date listed as 1892-02-05 in Germany.
Parents listed as Wilhelm Seehafer and Wilhelmina Boelter.
Usual residence listed as  509 Long Shore Dr (Ann Arbor).
Burial listed at Fair View Cemetery (Ann Arbor).
Source: Michigan Death Certificate: Ida M. Seehafer (1948)

Rebecca Seehafer
Facts

Birth date listed as 1865-07-08 in Germany.
Married to Julius Seehafer (listed on death certificate).
Residence listed as 1262 Pontiac St, Ann Arbor.
Died on 1919-08-05 in Ann Arbor, Michigan; cause of death listed as cerebral syphilis.
Burial listed at Fair View Cemetery (Ann Arbor) on 1919-08-08.

Household Context

Ann Arbor city directories list Julius Seehafer at 1202 Pontiac St (Ann Arbor) in the same period as Wanda Seehafer; this may reflect a household network (Unconfirmed linkage to Rebecca).
TODO: Verify whether 1262 Pontiac and 1202 Pontiac refer to the same household or nearby residences.

Death

Date of death: 1919-08-05 in Ann Arbor, Michigan.
Cause of death: Cerebral syphilis; contributory cause listed as [illegible].
Informant: Julius Seehafer.
Source: Michigan Death Certificate: Rebecca Seehafer (1919)

research-log/facts-to-date.title: facts-to-date
research-log/facts-to-date.content:
Facts to Date
Overview
This summary captures only the facts currently recorded in this repo. It is intentionally conservative and avoids speculation.
As more documents are added, this file should be updated with citations to those sources.
Family Tree Snapshot

Seehafer family: Clara F., Ida M., Bertha A., William Gottlieb, Wilhelmina Boelter, Alvina Helena.
Source: Rememberances of the Seehafer Family as Heard From Mom on Trip to Poland
Stoeckle family: John Duane, Edward Max Jr., Katherine Friederike Nuffer Stoeckle.
Source: (not yet in repo)

research-log/records-playbook.title: records-playbook
research-log/records-playbook.content:
Records & Requests Playbook
Michigan death certificates

You can request from the county clerk (county where the death occurred) or from the state.
Provide full name, date of death, place of death, and parents/spouse if known.
TODO: Add current county and state request links and fees.

Probate packets (Washtenaw / Jackson)

Ask the probate court for the full estate file or probate packet, including petitions, inventories, and final orders.
Provide the decedent’s full name, approximate death date, and county.
TODO: Add the contact details for Washtenaw and Jackson probate courts.

Census images for hospitals

Use FamilySearch image browsing if names are not indexed.
Look for enumeration district (ED) maps tied to the hospital.
TODO: Add the specific EDs for Pontiac State Hospital and Ypsilanti State Hospital once confirmed.

Template email
Subject: Records request for [Full Name], died [Date]
Hello,
I am requesting a copy of the death certificate / probate packet for [Full Name], who died on [Date] in [County, State].
If possible, please include the full file and any related documents.
Thank you,
[Your Name]
[Contact Info]
Call script
“Hi, I’m requesting a death certificate / probate packet for [Full Name], who died on [Date] in [County]. Can you tell me the process, fees, and what information you need from me?”
Missing artifacts checklist

 Bertha A. Seehafer death certificate (1960)
 Katherine Friederike (Nufer) Stoeckle death certificate (1932)
 Probate packets for Clara, Ida, Bertha
 Obituaries: Jackson Citizen-Patriot (1932); Ann Arbor News (1916, 1948, 1960)

sources/jds-memories.title: Rememberances of Sturgis as Heard From John D Stoeckle
sources/jds-memories.content:
Rememberances of Sturgis as Heard From John D Stoeckle
Summary
Memoir-style recollections attributed to John D. Stoeckle. The document describes family life in Sturgis and references Seehafer family history and locations. A copy is stored at content/sources/raw/JDS memories.docx.
Key Extracted Claims

Unconfirmed: John D. Stoeckle states he and Janet were born in Highland Park, near Detroit.
Unconfirmed: The family lived at 606 Laurel Ave in Sturgis for about 14 years, with earlier and later moves within Sturgis.
Unconfirmed: The Seehafer family came from West Pomerania and immigrated in 1902, first to Minnesota and then to Ann Arbor.
Unconfirmed: The Seehafer family had a house at 509 Cedar Street in Ann Arbor and Uncle Bill inherited it.
Unconfirmed: Two Seehafer sisters were hospitalized at the state mental hospital in Ypsilanti; one death certificate (Bertha, 1960) listed schizophrenia.

People Mentioned

John Duane Stoeckle
Ida M. Seehafer
Bertha A. Seehafer

Places Mentioned

Ypsilanti State Hospital
 Long Shore Dr (Ann Arbor)

Follow-up Research

Verify the 509 Cedar Street address with city directories and property records.
Locate the referenced Bertha death certificate and confirm diagnosis details.
Confirm the immigration timeline with passenger lists and naturalization records.

sources/seehafer-rememberances-trip-to-p.title: Rememberances of the Seehafer Family as Heard From Mom on Trip to Poland
sources/seehafer-rememberances-trip-to-p.content:
Rememberances of the Seehafer Family as Heard From Mom on Trip to Poland
Summary
Family reminiscence document focused on the Seehafer family, immigration, and later recollections, including a trip to Poland. A copy is stored at content/sources/raw/REMEMBERANCES OF THE SEEHAFER FAMILY AS HEARD FROM MOM AND TRIP TO POLAND.docx.
Key Extracted Claims

Unconfirmed: The Seehafer family traveled from Bremen, Germany to Baltimore, arriving September 18, 1902; only parents, Ida, and “Mom” were listed on the steamship document.
Unconfirmed: The family first went to Minnesota near St. Paul, then moved to Ann Arbor, Michigan where the father set up a shop as a foundry man.
Unconfirmed: Uncle Bill (Wilhelm Seehafer) was born April 29, 1888 in Germany and died April 13, 1958 in Ann Arbor.
Unconfirmed: Ida died in 1948; two sisters were hospitalized at the Ypsilanti mental hospital.
Unconfirmed: The grandparents Wilhelm (1921) and Wilhilmine (1922) died before the author was born.

People Mentioned

Ida M. Seehafer
Bertha A. Seehafer

Places Mentioned

Ypsilanti State Hospital

Follow-up Research

Locate the passenger list for the September 18, 1902 arrival in Baltimore.
Verify Wilhelm Seehafer’s birth and death dates with vital records.
Confirm the identities of the two sisters hospitalized in Ypsilanti.

start-here.title: Start Here
start-here.content:
Start Here
What this site is
This is a shared family history notebook for the Seehafer and Stoeckle families. It keeps facts, sources, and open questions in one place so research stays organized and transparent.

If you only read one thing, start with Facts to Date.

How to navigate

People: individual profiles and confirmed life details.
Places: addresses, towns, and institutions tied to the family.
Sources: primary documents and citations.
Research Log: open questions, requests, and progress notes.

Confirmed vs Unconfirmed

Confirmed facts are supported by sources listed on the page.
Unconfirmed items are marked clearly and kept in TODOs or open questions until evidence is added.

Privacy note
Please avoid sharing sensitive information about living people in public.
